p.s: Description of Roseomonas terrae sp. nov.
Roseomonas terrae (ter′rae. L. gen. n. terrae of the soil).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming coccobacilli (0.6–0.9×0.6–3.0 μm).
Colonies on 2× diluted NA are circular, convex, smooth, glistening, pale yellow to pale pink in colour and 0.5–0.8 mm in diameter after incubation for 7 days at 25 °C.
Optimal growth occurs at 25 °C; growth occurs weakly at 10 and 36 °C, but not at 4 or 37 °C.
Optimal pH for growth is between 7.0 and 8.0; growth occurs at pH 5.5 and 10.5, but not at pH 5.0 or 11.0.
Growth occurs in the presence of 0–1.0 % (w/v), with an optimum in the presence of 0.5 % (w/v) NaCl.
Growth does not occur under anaerobic conditions on 2× diluted NA or on 2× diluted NA supplemented with nitrate.
H2S and indole are not produced.
None of the substrates in the API 20NE and API 50CH strips is utilized as a sole carbon source.
The major fatty acids (>10 % of total fatty acids) are C18 : 1ω7c (63.9 %) and C18 : 1 2-OH (10.3 %).
The DNA G+C content is 69.3 mol% (HPLC).
Other phenotypic properties are shown in Table 1 (see also Supplementary Table S1 available in IJSEM Online).
The type strain, DS-48T (=KCTC 12874T=JCM 14592T), was isolated from soil from Dokdo in Korea.
